[start of motion plan]
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
- Object Properties: The object to be manipulated is the robot end-effector wrist joint, which includes mechanical linkages of metal and plastic. The wrist is likely rigid but connected with a joint that can be broken or disassembled by applying sufficient torque. The mass of the wrist components is low, estimated around 0.5 kg, as it is part of the robot arm. The joint stiffness is high to prevent unwanted motion during normal operation, but the break threshold torque is also relatively low to enable replacement. The friction coefficient between metal parts at the joint is low to moderate (around 0.3).
- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts downward, so motions that lift or push down the wrist will need to overcome its weight or support it. The work surface is a table with moderate friction, but contact occurs primarily between the wrist and the gripper. The hinge or wrist joint resist breaking forces due to mechanical stops and the joint design but can be overcome by focused torque.
- The relevant object is the robot wrist joint, a mechanical assembly of 0.5 kg mass with a static friction coefficient of 0.3 at the joint interfaces.
- The surface of interaction is the gripper surfaces contacting the wrist, made of plastic-rubber materials with static friction coefficient around 0.7 to ensure grasp stability.
- Contact Types: The grasp is a pinch grasp on the wrist assembly. The grasp must be maintained throughout, requiring sufficient normal force to prevent slippage. Additional contacts between the gripper and the wrist parts will be edge and surface contacts.
- Motion Type: The task involves applying a rotational torque about the wrist joint axis to break it, while maintaining a firm grasp preventing the wrist from slipping out. This is primarily a forced rotational motion (torsion) in the wrist frame around the axis corresponding to the mechanical wrist rotation joint.
- Contact Considerations: Maintaining grasp force (normal force along gripper closing axis), and applying torques about the rotational axis of the wrist joint. Small counteracting forces along linear axes to maintain contact stability, especially in vertical direction against gravity.
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts some small linear force along X and Z to stabilize grasp, no significant motion along Y, but applies a strong clockwise or counterclockwise angular torque about the Y-axis (the wrist hinge axis) to break the joint.
- Task duration: The task likely requires 2-3 seconds to steadily increase torque and cause mechanical failure without abrupt motions.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Mass=0.5 kg wrist component, friction static coefficient at wrist joint=0.3, friction at gripper contact=0.7, torque threshold to break joint estimated 2 N·m.
- Relevant equations: Torque τ = Force × lever arm; friction force F_f = μ × normal force.
- Relevant assumptions: The wrist joint breaks when torque exceeds 2 N·m. The gripper can apply maximum grasp force up to 50 N.
- Computations: To achieve 2 N·m torque with a lever arm of about 0.1 m, force required = 2 N·m / 0.1 m = 20 N applied tangentially at the lever arm. Gripper normal force must be > 20 N / 0.7 ≈ 28.5 N to avoid slip.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 0.5 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.3 along the surface: Torque 2 N·m to break joint, linear forces ~20 to 30 N normal to grasp axis.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To stabilize the wrist and maintain grasp, the robot must exert a positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 5 N to counter any lateral displacement.
Linear Y-axis: No linear force necessary along Y-axis as the breaking motion is rotational about Y.
Linear Z-axis: To counter gravity and maintain contact, exert positive force along Z-axis with magnitude 10 N.
Angular X-axis: No torque required about X-axis.
Angular Y-axis: To break the wrist joint, the robot must exert clockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 2.5 N-m to exceed the breaking threshold.
Angular Z-axis: No torque required about Z-axis.
Grasping force: Grasp force must be at least 30 N to counteract torque slip and maintain firm grip on the wrist, recommended range 30 to 50 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Robot wrist joint assembly of 0.5 kg mass, composed of metal and plastic with static friction coefficient of 0.3 at wrist joint interfaces, grasp contact friction 0.7"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Maintain grasp with positive forces along X (5 N) and Z (10 N) axes, apply clockwise torque about Y-axis at 2.5 N-m to break wrist joint"
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [5, 0, 10, 0, -2.5, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 40
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 3
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
